questions.text: Identify the vertebral level of section in given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T9

 

The provided image shows a cross-sectional anatomy where key structures such as the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs are visible. At the T9 vertebral level, the liver and stomach are seen prominently, with the heart also visible, indicating that the section is at the level where these thoracic and upper abdominal structures overlap. The presence of the lungs further supports that this is a thoracic level.

 

 

 

Cross sectional anatomy of ABDOMEN:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T10: While the T10 level also shows some of the same structures, the visibility and position of the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs in this image are more indicative of T9.

 

Option C. T11: At the T11 level, the kidneys start to become visible, and the heart is usually not as prominent as it is at the T9 level.

 

Option D. T12: The T12 level typically shows the kidneys more clearly and does not include as much of the heart and upper liver as seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The T9 vertebral level in cross-sectional anatomy images often shows the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs, making it a key point for identifying these structures.

questions.text: Bleeding as shown in the image is due to which of the following vessels?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bridging veins

 

The image demonstrating a bleed over the arachnoid layer but beneath the dura suggests a subdural hemorrhage. It is most commonly caused by the shearing of cortical bridging veins.

 

A subdural hemorrhage is a type of intracranial hemorrhage, which is bleeding within the skull. It occurs when blood accumulates between the dura mater (the tough outermost layer of the meninges) and the arachnoid mater (the middle layer of the meninges) surrounding the brain.

 

Subdural hemorrhages are usually caused by trauma to the head, such as falls or motor vehicle accidents, which can tear the veins that bridge the dura and arachnoid layers. The bleeding can create pressure on the brain, leading to neurological symptoms such as headaches, confusion, dizziness, seizures, and in severe cases, coma or death.

 

The symptoms of a subdural hemorrhage can develop immediately or may take hours or even days to appear, depending on the severity of the bleeding. In some cases, a small subdural hemorrhage may resolve on its own without treatment, while larger or more severe bleeds may require surgery to relieve pressure on the brain and stop the bleeding.

 

Factors that can increase the risk of a subdural hemorrhage include advanced age, alcohol or drug abuse, blood-thinning medications, and medical conditions that affect blood clotting or increase the risk of falls. Early recognition and treatment of a subdural hemorrhage can improve outcomes and prevent complications.

 

Dx:- Non-Contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle meningeal artery rupture would result in an extradural hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Lenticulostriate artery would lead to an intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Vertebral artery dissection leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage or sometimes intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognition of a subdural hemorrhage is crucial following head trauma, especially in individuals at higher risk such as the elderly, those on anticoagulation therapy, or those with a history of alcohol abuse. Immediate medical evaluation is vital to manage the condition effectively and mitigate potential severe outcomes.

questions.text: A young child with absent thymus is brought to the OPD with features of hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following marked area in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12

 

The patient most certainly has DiGeorge syndrome based on the clinical history and the imaging, which displays pharyngeal pouches (thymic and parathyroid defects). It might be brought on by faulty third- and fourth-pharyngeal-pocket development. The thymus' absence is expressly stated in the provided stem. Hence, choice 12 is the better of the two.

 

  • DiGeorge syndrome is a complex embryopathy that is caused by hemizygous interstitial deletion of chromosome 22, leading to multiple developmental defects, including conotruncal defects, hypoparathyroidism, and dysmorphic syndrome. Microdeletion at chromosome 22q11 can lead to variable presentations including -
  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia leading to T-cell deficiency
  • Cardiac defects
  • Hypocalcemia 2° to parathyroid aplasia.

          (Mnemonic: CATCH-22)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9 : External Auditory Meatus. The first pharyngeal pouch derivatives include the middle ear cavity, eustachian tube, and external auditory meatus. These structures are primarily involved in auditory functions and do not relate to the endocrine or immune system anomalies seen in DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option B. 10: Palatine Tonsil. The second pharyngeal pouch develops into the palatine tonsils. While DiGeorge syndrome can include a range of pharyngeal derivatives issues, the palatine tonsil is not typically affected in ways that lead to the major clinical symptoms of thymus and parathyroid gland absence.

 

Option D. 14: Ultimobranchial Body. This derivative of the fourth pharyngeal pouch contributes to the development of the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid, which are responsible for calcitonin production. Although related to calcium metabolism, its involvement is distinct from the parathyroid gland's role in calcium homeostasis and does not directly relate to the primary symptoms of DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The most relevant site of defect in DiGeorge syndrome, given the symptoms described (absent thymus, hypoparathyroidism, and tetany), is associated with abnormalities in the third pharyngeal pouch—specifically the development of the inferior parathyroid glands and the thymus

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization?  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Genitofemoral nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Genitofemoral nerve is blocked when the local anesthetic is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization.

 

The genitofemoral nerve is a mixed nerve that arises from the anterior divisions of the L1 and L2 spinal nerves. It descends through the psoas major muscle and emerges from the lateral border of the muscle. It then divides into two branches: The genital branch, which supplies sensory fibers to the skin of the mons pubis, labia majora or scrotum, and cremaster muscle in males.

 

The femoral branch, which passes laterally over the iliacus muscle and descends along the anterior surface of the psoas major muscle. It supplies sensory fibers to the skin of the femoral triangle and the upper anterior thigh.

 

In addition to its sensory functions, the genitofemoral nerve also provides motor innervation to the cremaster muscle in males, which raises the testes towards the body in response to cold or other stimuli. Dysfunction of the genitofemoral nerve can lead to sensory loss or motor weakness in the areas it innervates.

 

 

During femoral vein catheterization, local anesthesia is typically administered in the area inferior to the inguinal ligament and close to the femoral pulse. Among the given options, the genitofemoral nerve is the one most likely to be anesthetized during this procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve is the largest branch of the lumbar plexus and arises from the dorsal divisions of the ventral rami of the L2-L4 spinal nerves. It descends through the iliopsoas muscle and enters the femoral triangle, lateral to the femoral vessels. The femoral nerve primarily supplies muscles in the anterior compartment of the thigh and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. While it is in close proximity to the femoral vein, it is not the primary nerve targeted during femoral vein catheterization.

 

Option C. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh: This nerve originates from the L2-L3 levels of the lumbar plexus. It travels inferiorly and exits the pelvis under the inguinal ligament, close to the anterior superior iliac spine, to supply the skin on the lateral aspect of the thigh. While it is near the inguinal ligament, its location is more lateral compared to the site of femoral vein catheterization, making it less likely to be affected.

 

Option D. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve arises from the L1 level of the lumbar plexus. It travels through the inguinal canal and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the groin, mons pubis, and scrotum or labium majus. The course and distribution of this nerve make it less relevant for femoral vein catheterization, which occurs more medially and inferiorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genitofemoral nerve arises from the L1-L2 levels of the lumbar plexus. It descends on the anterior surface of the psoas major muscle and then splits into two branches: the genital and femoral branches. The femoral branch pierces the fascia lata to provide sensory innervation to a small area of skin over the femoral triangle. Given its anatomical location and course, this nerve is likely to be anesthetized during femoral vein catheterization.

questions.text: Match the following : (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D
 

Explanation:

 

  1. Facial nerve - B. Taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue: The facial nerve (CN VII) is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It also controls the muscles of facial expression.
  2. Spinal accessory nerve - A. Shrugging of the shoulder: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) innervates the trapezius muscle, which is responsible for actions such as shrugging the shoulder and scapula elevation. It also contributes to head rotation.
  3. Glossopharyngeal nerve - C. Taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue. It also plays a role in swallowing and provides sensory information from the throat and tonsils.
  4. Mandibular nerve - D. Chewing: The mandibular nerve (V3) is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and is responsible for innervating the muscles of mastication (chewing), as well as providing sensory input to the lower jaw, teeth, and gums.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fibrous joint

 

Explanation:

 

The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis).

 

Fibrous joints are joints where bones are connected by fibrous tissue, such as ligaments or sutures.

 

Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the syndesmosis between the radius and ulna at the distal radioulnar joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plane synovial: Plane synovial joints are also known as gliding joints. They allow for limited gliding or sliding movements between flat articular surfaces. Examples of plane synovial joints include the intercarpal joints of the wrist.

 

Option B. Primary cartilaginous: Primary cartilaginous joints, also called synchondroses, are joints where bones are connected by hyaline cartilage. An example of a primary cartilaginous joint is the epiphyseal plate in growing long bones.

 

Option C. Secondary cartilaginous: Secondary cartilaginous joints, or symphyses, are joints where bones are connected by fibrocartilage. Examples include the intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Three joints connect the radius and ulna to one another:

 

  • Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • Middle radioulnar joint
  • Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint

 

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

 

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

 

  1. The oblique cord - extends distally from the radial tuberosity to the radius from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity.
  2. Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

questions.text: Identify the liver segment star marked in the image below:  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. V

 

Segment V of the liver is highlighted in green in this CT scan. The CT section shown is taken below the portal vein, allowing a cross-section of the portal vein before its bifurcation to be seen.

 

A horizontal plane known as the portal plane divides the liver where the portal vein bifurcates and becomes horizontal. This divides each section of the liver into superior and inferior segments:

 

  • Left lateral section: segment II above and segment III below the portal plane
  • Left medial section: segment IVa above and segment Ib below the portal plane
  • Right anterior (or medial) section: segment VIll above and segment V below the portal plane
  • Right posterior (or lateral section): segment VIl above and segment VI below the portal plane

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (IVa): Incorrect because Segment IVa is located in the left medial section of the liver and is positioned above the portal plane. This segment does not correlate with the green highlighted area in the provided image.

 

Option C (VII): Incorrect as Segment VII is part of the right posterior (or lateral) section of the liver and is located above the portal plane, unlike the depicted segment.

 

Option D (I): Incorrect because Segment I, also known as the caudate lobe, is uniquely positioned and does not conform to the typical left-right segmentation. It is not visible in the typical transverse sections used for identifying other segments like V.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which muscles receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Gluteus Medius

2. Gluteus Minimus

3. Tensor fascia lata

4. Piriformis
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3

 

Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, S1) supplies to Gluteus Medius, Minimus and Tensor Fascia Lata (damage leads to positive Trendelenburg sign). Accompanied by the superior gluteal vessels, the nerve leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen above piriformis, and divides into superior and inferior branches. The superior branch accompanies the upper branch of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery to supply gluteus medius and occasionally gluteus minimus. The inferior branch runs with the lower ramus of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery across gluteus minimus, supplies the glutei medius and minimus and ends in tensor fasciae latae.

 

Piriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis (S1, S2).

 

 

1. Gluteus Medius: True. The gluteus medius muscle receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This nerve supplies motor neurons to the gluteus medius and plays a crucial role in the abduction and stabilization of the hip joint.
 

2. Gluteus Minimus: True. Similar to the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus muscle is also innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. It functions in hip abduction and stabilization.
 

3. Tensor Fascia Lata (TFL): True. The tensor fascia lata muscle, often referred to as the TFL, receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This muscle assists in various movements, including flexion, abduction, and medial rotation of the hip.

 

Other Option

 

4. Piriformis: False. The piriformis muscle is not innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the nerve to the piriformis, which arises from the sacral plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluteus Medius, Gluteus Minimus, and Tensor Fascia Lata receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, and S1 nerve roots). Piriformis, on the other hand, is innervated by one of the branch of sacral plexus.

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deep perineal pouch

 

Option B. Deep perineal pouch: This is a space situated superior to the perineal membrane and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It contains the membranous urethra, deep transverse perineal muscles, and parts of the external urethral sphincter. Extravasation of urine is possible in deep perineal pouch.

 

When there is a rupture of the penile urethra (often due to trauma, such as a straddle injury), the extravasation of urine and blood can occur into various anatomical spaces, depending on the location and nature of the injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial perineal pouch: This is a space located in the urogenital triangle of the perineum, bounded above by the perineal membrane and below by the perineal (Colles') fascia. The pouch contains the root of the penis (including the bulb of the penis) and the associated muscles. A rupture of the penile urethra can cause extravasation of urine and blood into this space.

 

Option C. Skin around penis. The skin around base of penis may get involved if the rupture is located in the bulbous part of urethra.

 

Option D. Skin around the scrotum: With a rupture of the penile urethra, especially if the rupture occurs in the bulbous part located within the superficial perineal pouch, the extravasated urine and blood can dissect through the fascial layers and present as swelling and bruising around the scrotum and base of the penis. This is often referred to as a "butterfly" pattern of bruising, as the extravasated fluid can spread anteriorly onto the anterior abdominal wall and laterally to the thighs but is typically limited superiorly by Scarpa's fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

questions.text: Which of the following bony structures is present behind the marked area? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lesser wing of sphenoid

 

The pterion is a point on the side of the skull where several bones meet, including the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. The lesser wing of the sphenoid is one of the bones that contributes to the formation of the pterion. It's an important landmark because it's located just behind the pterion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post clivus: The clivus is a bony ridge on the occipital bone, and it is located at the base of the skull. The "post clivus" isn't a commonly used term in anatomy, and it's not directly related to the pterion.

 

Option C. Sella turcica: The sella turcica is a saddle-shaped depression in the sphenoid bone where the pituitary gland is located. It is situated more toward the center of the skull, behind the eyes and nasal cavity, and is not directly related to the pterion.

 

Option D. Carotid canal: The carotid canal is a passage in the temporal bone that houses the internal carotid artery. It is located deeper within the skull, closer to the middle ear, and is not directly related to the pterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

1. Frontal bone

2. Squamous part of the temporal bone

3. Greater wing of the sphenoid bone

4. Parietal bone

questions.text:
What are the derivatives of the marked cells? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Odontoblasts

2. Sympathetic chain

3. Melanocytes

4. Nephrogenic cord

5. Bulbus cordis

6. Conotruncal septum
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3, 6

 

Explanation

 

The cells referred to in the question are neural crest cells (NCC), identified adjacent to the neural tube (NT). These cells are significant in developmental biology and are often considered a fourth germ layer due to their extensive differentiation potential across various organs and tissues, exclusive to vertebrates. NCCs transform into various cell types based on their migration path:

 

Dorsal region migration leads to the formation of sensory neurons.

 

Ventral region migration results in the differentiation into sympathetic neurons.

 

These cells are pivotal in developing peripheral nervous system components, craniofacial structures (including bones, cartilage, teeth, and facial muscles), and cardiovascular system components such as the heart.

 

1. Odontoblasts : Correct, as these are the cells responsible for dentin formation in teeth, derived from neural crest cells.

 

2. Sympathetic chain : Correct, neural crest cells form the sympathetic ganglia, part of the autonomic nervous system.

 

3. Melanocytes : Correct, these pigment-producing cells in the skin and hair are derived from neural crest cells.

 

6. Conotruncal septum : Correct, this component of the heart, crucial for the division of the pulmonary artery and aorta, is derived from neural crest cells.

 

In trunk region, NCC form:

 

  • Melanocytes
  • Sensory ganglia
  • Sympathetic and enteric neurons
  • Schwann cells
  • Adrenal medulla cells
  • In the cranial region, they contribute to the:
  • Craniofacial skeleton
  • Neurons for cranial ganglia
  • Satellite glial cells
  • Melanocytes
  • Some of the other neural crest derivatives are
  • C cells of the thyroid gland
  • Conotruncal septum in the heart
  • Odontoblasts
  • Smooth muscle cells to blood vessels to the face and forebrain.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Nephrogenic cord : Incorrect, as it is involved in the development of the kidneys and does not derive from neural crest cells.

 

5. Bulbus cordis : Incorrect, this embryonic heart structure does not originate from neural crest cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural crest cells (NCCs), stemming from the embryonic ectoderm and unique to vertebrates, play an essential role in forming various tissues and organs like the peripheral nervous system and craniofacial structures during development. These cells migrate and differentiate into diverse cell types based on their location in the body, contributing significantly to the development of sensory and sympathetic neurons, craniofacial elements, and cardiovascular structures.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with symptoms of inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits. He was also not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

Explanation:

 

An ulnar nerve damage is suggested by the clinical scenario, which includes a positive card test and the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits.

 

The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle: site C

 

 

Damage to the ulnar nerve at the medial epicondyle causes paralysis of the flexor carpi ulnaris (lack of ulnar deviation) and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (loss of distal interphalangeal joint flexion). Hypothenar paralysis (which causes atrophy) and sensory loss are the results. Moreover, the extensor digitorum and flexor digitorum superficialis (provided by the radial nerve and median nerve, respectively) continue to function. The third and fourth digits are therefore not completely paralysed. The palmar interossei's fragility, which causes a loss of adduction, is what causes the positive card test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head of the Humerus: Articulates with the shoulder joint. Injury here typically affects shoulder movement, not the distal functions like finger flexion or sensory issues associated with the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. Intertubercular Groove: Houses the tendon of the biceps brachii. Mainly affects movements related to the biceps muscle, not ulnar nerve functions.

 

Option D. Lateral Epicondyle: Attachment site for forearm extensor muscles. Primarily involved in conditions like lateral epicondylitis, which causes localized pain rather than the broader sensory and motor deficits seen in ulnar nerve damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulnar nerve branches and supply:

 

 

Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

questions.text:
Inferior thyroid artery supply which of the following structure?

 

1. Thyroid

2. Parathyroid

3. Esophagus

4. Thymus
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. 1, 2, 3 & 4

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk and arises from the subclavian artery. It runs upward in front of the vertebral column and enters the thyroid gland at its lower pole. Along its course, the inferior thyroid artery gives off several branches that supply the thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and the pharynx.

 

  1. Thyroid: The inferior thyroid artery primarily supplies blood to the thyroid gland. The gland requires a substantial blood supply due to its high metabolic activity, especially when it's actively producing thyroid hormones. The inferior thyroid artery enters the thyroid gland at its posterior aspect and supplies the majority of the gland, especially its inferior portion.
  2. Parathyroid: The parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland. There are usually four parathyroid glands: two superior and two inferior. The inferior parathyroid glands are typically supplied by the inferior thyroid artery. The blood supply to these glands is crucial because they produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a vital role in calcium homeostasis.
  3. Esophagus: The esophagus, especially its cervical portion, may receive some blood supply from the branches of the inferior thyroid artery. However, it's essential to note that the primary blood supply to the esophagus comes from the esophageal branches of various arteries along its length, such as the aorta and the left gastric artery.
  4. Thymus: While the inferior thyroid artery is not a primary source of blood supply for the thymus, there can be some anastomotic connections between the vessels supplying these structures in the anterior mediastinum. However, the primary blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic and anterior mediastinal branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyroid gland receives its main arterial blood supply from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries. The inferior thyroid artery also supplies the parathyroid glands with blood. Additionally, its branches provide blood to the esophagus, larynx, trachea, thymus and pharynx.

 

Branches:

 

  • Pharyngeal branches
  • Ascending cervical artery
  • Inferior artery
  • Muscular branches

 

Thymic branches – originate from internal thoracic, inferior thyroid arteryand often superior thyroid arteries & supply the thymus.

questions.text: Fibers from the structure marked in blue, terminate at which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Red nucleus

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle is the peduncle that is highlighted in the picture. Deep cerebellar nuclei that extend to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus are connected by fibres to the superior cerebellar peduncle. The fibres of the ventral spinocerebellar tract are also present.

 

 

 

All of the efferent fibres from the dentate, emboliform, and globose nuclei Majority of efferents from the fastigial nucleus pass via inferior cerebellar peduncle though few may pass via superior peduncle. The caudal mesencephalon is where its fibres decussate, and they are intended to synapse in the thalamus and opposite red nucleus. Only afferent fibres from the contralateral pontine nuclei are present in the middle cerebellar peduncle. Afferent and efferent fibres that travel to the vestibular nuclei are both present in the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

The image below summarizes the various tracts in the cerebellar unit.

 

 

  • It has two surfaces - superior and inferior separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles
    • Superior cerebellar peduncle -connecting to the midbrain
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the pons
    • Inferior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the medulla oblongata

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle, also known as the brachium conjunctivum, is a major white matter tract connecting the cerebellum to the midbrain. Its fibers originate in the cerebellum, ascend, and decussate (cross over) at the level of the midbrain to end primarily in the contralateral red nucleus and the thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fastigial nucleus: The fastigial nucleus is one of the four deep cerebellar nuclei (others being the globose, emboliform, and dentate nuclei). While the fastigial nucleus does send fibers out of the cerebellum, it primarily connects through the inferior cerebellar peduncle to the vestibular nuclei and the reticular formation, not the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option B. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is involved in motor learning and coordination. It primarily sends fibers to the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle, and it receives cerebellar feedback, but not directly from the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option D. Subthalamus: The subthalamus is part of the diencephalon and is closely related to the basal ganglia circuitry, particularly in the indirect pathway. While the subthalamus does receive some cerebellar input, the primary connection from the superior cerebellar peduncle is to the red nucleus and not directly to the subthalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The red nucleus is located in the midbrain and plays a role in motor coordination. Fibers from the cerebellum via the superior cerebellar peduncle decussate and terminate primarily in the contralateral red nucleus. From the red nucleus, some of these fibers continue on to the thalamus. Thus, the red nucleus is a major target of the superior cerebellar peduncle fibers.

questions.text: Calcium deposition is seen in which layer? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Calcium deposition occurs primarily in the zone of calcified cartilage, which is represented by option D in the image. This zone is located near the metaphysis of a growing bone, where cartilage is being replaced by bone tissue. The calcification process involves the accumulation of calcium salts in the cartilage matrix, leading to its hardening and subsequent replacement by bone. This is a crucial step in the endochondral ossification process, which allows for the longitudinal growth of bones.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This layer represents the reserve zone, where chondrocytes are relatively inactive and not yet undergoing proliferation or hypertrophy. Calcium deposition does not occur in this zone.

 

Option B: This layer is the proliferative zone, where chondrocytes are rapidly dividing. While important for bone growth, this zone does not involve calcium deposition.

 

Option C: This is the hypertrophic zone, where chondrocytes increase in size and prepare for calcification. Although it is a precursor to the calcification process, actual calcium deposition occurs in the next zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zone of calcified cartilage is where calcium deposition occurs, leading to the hardening of cartilage and its eventual replacement by bone during the growth of long bones.

questions.text:
Which of the following are a part of the limbic system?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Amygdala

2. Hippocampus

3. Thalamus
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

The limbic system is a complex set of brain structures located on both sides of the thalamus, immediately beneath the cerebrum. It includes key components such as the amygdala, hippocampus, thalamus, hypothalamus, basal ganglia, and cingulate gyrus. These structures support a variety of functions related to emotions, behavior, motivation, long-term memory, and olfaction.

 

  1. Amygdala: Integral for processing emotions, the amygdala is especially involved in fear, anxiety, and social cognition. It also plays a significant role in forming and retrieving emotional memories.
  2. Hippocampus: Essential for learning and memory, the hippocampus is pivotal in the consolidation of information from short-term memory to long-term memory and spatial navigation.
  3. Thalamus: Although primarily known as the relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, the thalamus also supports functions of the limbic system by regulating consciousness, sleep, and alertness.

 

Other structures are :

 

The hypothalamus is involved in regulating many bodily functions, including hunger, thirst, body temperature, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a key role in the regulation of the autonomic nervous system and the endocrine system.

 

The cingulate gyrus is involved in a variety of functions, including emotion regulation, attention, and the processing of pain.

 

Together, these structures form a complex network that plays a crucial role in many aspects of human behavior and cognition. Dysfunction or damage to the limbic system can lead to a range of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including Alzheimer's disease, depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The limbic system’s role is critical, as its structures are deeply integrated into the processes governing emotions, memory, and essential physiological functions. Damage or dysfunction in any part of the limbic system can lead to profound psychological and cognitive impairments, affecting everything from emotional regulation to memory processing.

questions.text: The structures marked in the image below are found in the epithelial lining of all of the following sites, except? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epididymis

 

The picture depicts an arrow mark pointing in the direction of the cilia. All of the structures listed as choices have ciliated lining epithelia, with the exception of the epididymis, which has pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia, that’s play a role in sperm maturation and storage.

 

The given image is a histological section of the epididymis showing the pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia.

 

 

Cilia are minute hair-like projections, while stereocilia are very long, thick microvilli measuring about 5-10 um in length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oviduct (Fallopian Tube): The oviduct, also known as the Fallopian tube, is a part of the female reproductive system. It contains ciliated epithelium, which helps in the transport of the egg from the ovary to the uterus. The cilia in the oviduct assist in moving the egg and help in the fertilization process.

 

Option C. Bronchi: The bronchi are part of the respiratory system and are responsible for conducting air to and from the lungs. They contain ciliated epithelium to help move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Ependyma : it is a type of neuroglial cell that lines the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. It contains ciliated epithelium, which assists in the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciliated epithelium:

 

  • The epithelium bears cilia, which moves in a coordinated fashion, and help in the movement of the mucus, or propel the movement of any other structures such as ova or spermatozoa.
  • The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.
  • The pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is seen in the trachea and in large bronchi.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The primary actions of the gluteus maximus are hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are important for movements like standing up from a sitting position, climbing stairs, and running.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abduction and external rotation: The gluteus maximus does contribute to abduction but not external rotation. The primary muscles responsible for hip external rotation are the deep muscles of the hip joint i.e., Piriformis, gemelli superior and inferior, quadratus femoris.

 

Option C. Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation: While extension and lateral rotation are correct, adduction is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus. Adduction is more associated with the adductor muscles of the thigh (muscles of medial compartment of thigh).
 

 

Option D. Flexion and abduction: Flexion and abduction are not the primary actions of the gluteus maximus. These movements are primarily associated with other muscles like the iliopsoas for hip flexion and the tensor fasciae latae for hip abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus muscle, which is attached to the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, primarily performs hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are essential for tasks such as standing up, climbing stairs, and running. Remember, despite contributing to abduction, the gluteus maximus does not support external rotation as a primary action.

questions.text: A patient is unable to abduct his arm. Which of the following root values is likely to be affected? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C5

 

Explanation:

 

The most likely cause of the inability to abduct the arm is a C5 root lesion.

 

The C5 spinal nerve plays a crucial role in controlling shoulder abduction. It gives rise to the axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle. Damage or compression of the C5 nerve root or axillary nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to difficulty in abducting the arm.

 

Deltoid is supplied by axillary nerve which has the root value of C4-C6. The C5 component is responsible for abduction.Other components help in flexion and extensionm at shoulder joint

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C4: The C4 spinal nerve does not directly innervate the muscles responsible for shoulder abduction. It primarily supplies sensory information to areas of the neck and upper shoulders.

 

Option C. C6: The C6 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow flexion and wrist extension, not shoulder abduction. Damage to the C6 nerve root would affect these functions rather than shoulder abduction.

 

Option D. C7: The C7 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow and wrist flexion and finger extension. It is not directly involved in shoulder abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the shoulder

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior nucleus

 

The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is where the fibres from the mamillary body, which is the structure seen in the above figure, terminate.

 

The third ventricle's floor is made up of two tiny, hemispherical, pea-sized eminences called mammillary bodies, which are arranged side by side. The anterior thalamic nucleus receives fibres from the medial mammillary nucleus.

 

The anterior thalamic nuclei have 3 subdivisions -anteroventral nucleus, anteromedial nucleus, and anterodorsal nucleus.

 

  • Major input: Mammillothalamic tract from the mammillary nuclei of the hypothalamus.
  • Major cortical output: Anterior limbic area, cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyrus
  • Major function:
    • Regulation of alertness and attention
    • Acquisition of memory

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior nucleus: The posterior nuclear group, also known as the pulvinar, is the largest nuclear group in the thalamus. It is involved in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the posterior nucleus.

 

Option B. Reticular nucleus: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus surrounds the lateral aspect of the thalamus and serves as a modulator of information transfer between different parts of the thalamus and the cerebral cortex. It primarily functions to regulate the activity of relay nuclei in the thalamus. While it plays an important role in modulating thalamic function, the mammillothalamic tract does not primarily terminate here.

 

Option D. Ventral Lateral nucleus: The ventral lateral nucleus is one of the principal relay nuclei of the thalamus that receives inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia and projects to the primary motor cortex. It is involved in the coordination and planning of movements. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the ventral lateral nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior nuclear group of the thalamus is involved in emotional tone and recent memory. Fibers from the mammillary bodies, via the mammillothalamic tract, terminate in the anterior nuclei of the thalamus. The connection between the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nucleus is a crucial part of the Papez circuit.

questions.text: The marked structure develops from which of the following structures? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Supracardinal vein

 

The supracardinal vein gives rise to the structure indicated in the provided figure, which is the azygos vein.

 

The vein network known as the azygos system serves as a conduit between the superior and inferior venae caves. It resides in the posterior mediastinum and higher portion of the posterior abdominal wall. Moreover, it links the vertebral venous, caval, and portal systems. It drains the top part of the lumbar spine and the thoracic wall.

 

Development: The azygos venous system arises from the supra cardinal veins embryologically. The right supra cardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while the left supra cardinal vein becomes the hemiazygos vein.

 

  • The 4th to 11th right intercostal veins empties into the right supracardinal vein, which together with a portion of the posterior cardinal vein forms the azygos vein.
  • On the left, the 4th to 7th intercostal veins enters into the left supracardinal vein, and the left supracardinal vein, then known as the hemiazygos vein, which also empties into the azygos vein.
  • Cardinal veins form the main venous drainage system of the embryo. It consists of,
  • Anterior cardinal veins, which drain the cephalic part of the embryo, and
  • Posterior cardinal veins, which drain the rest of the embryo.

 

During the fifth to the seventh weeks, a number of additional veins are formed. It includes,

 

  • Subcardinal veins, which mainly drain the kidneys;
  • Sacrocardinal veins, which drain the lower extremities;
  • Supracardinal veins, which drain the body wall by way of the intercostal veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common cardinal vein: common cardinal veins drain the embryonic body into the sinus venosus. These are early, primitive venous systems that mainly regress but give rise to parts of the systemic venous system. Specifically, the common cardinal vein will give rise to the sinus venarum of the right atrium and the oblique vein of the left atrium.

 

Option B. Anterior cardinal vein: The anterior cardinal veins develop later and drain the cranial part of the embryo. With further development, the bilateral anterior cardinal veins will form the internal jugular vein and the brachiocephalic vein after some remodeling and anastomosis. It does not directly contribute to the formation of the azygos vein system.

 

Option D. Subcardinal vein: The subcardinal veins primarily play a role in the development of the renal and gonadal venous systems. They give rise to the renal segment of the inferior vena cava and the gonadal veins. They do not directly contribute to the formation of the azygos vein system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The supracardinal veins develop in the embryo as paired structures and are involved in the drainage of the body wall. On the right side, the supracardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while on the left side, it contributes to the formation of the hemiazygos and accessory hemiazygos veins.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the Green marked structure in the image in anatomical position? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coccyx

 

The marked structure in the image is the ischial spine. In anatomical position, the ischial spine is located at the level of the coccyx. This is important in various medical procedures, including the pudendal nerve block, commonly used in obstetrics and gynecology. The ischial spine serves as a significant landmark for these procedures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L4: Incorrect. The L4 vertebra is located much higher in the vertebral column, around the lower back region, and is not associated with the ischial spine.

 

Option B. L4-L5: Incorrect. This option refers to the intervertebral disc space between L4 and L5, which is also in the lower back but not related to the pelvic region or ischial spine.

 

Option C. S3-S5: Incorrect. Although the ischial spine can be aligned with these sacral vertebrae in certain positions like lithotomy (during childbirth), but here the question is about anatomical position so this is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ischial spine in anatomical position aligns with the coccyx, serving as an important landmark for various medical procedures.

questions.text: After parotidectomy, lower lip paralysis was seen in a patient. Which of the following part of facial nerve was involved ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

The cervical branch of the facial nerve is responsible for innervating the platysma muscle, which is crucial for controlling lower lip movements. During a parotidectomy, if this branch is damaged, it can lead to paralysis of the lower lip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid duct: The parotid duct is not a part of the facial nerve. It is a salivary duct and does not contribute to nerve innervation.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead, including the frontalis, corrugator supercilii, and orbicularis oculi. It does not affect lower lip movements.

 

Option D. Main trunk of facial nerve: The main trunk of the facial nerve divides into several branches, including the temporal and cervical branches. It is not directly responsible for the lower lip movement, as it provides the general innervation before splitting into specific branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the cervical branch of the facial nerve during a parotidectomy can result in lower lip paralysis.

questions.text: The cell marked in the black arrow below slide is inhibitory to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

 

The marked structure in the image is a flask-shaped neuron in the cerebellar cortex, which is a Purkinje cell. It is inhibitory to deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

The flask-shaped cells known as Purkinje cells are found in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum. They are positioned in a single layer between the molecular and granular cell layers, evenly spaced apart. Each cell's axon travels downhill, crosses the granular cell layer, and ends on the deep cerebellar nuclei, while each cell's dendrite travels upward to enter the molecular layer. They utilize GABA as their neurotransmitter and are inhibitory.

 

Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex. They receive excitatory input from the climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus and mossy fibers.

 

Pathological significance of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Negri bodies in rabies are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum.
  • In paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells due to antibodies directed against them.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vestibular nuclei: The vestibular nuclei are located in the brainstem and are primarily involved in processing information related to balance and spatial orientation from the inner ear. While Purkinje cells can send inhibitory outputs that influence the activity of the vestibular nuclei indirectly, it is not their direct and primary target.

 

Option C. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata of the brainstem. It sends excitatory inputs to the cerebellum, specifically to the Purkinje cells, via climbing fibers. These fibers have a strong excitatory influence on Purkinje cells, but Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the inferior olivary nucleus.

 

Option D. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei in the brain that are associated with a variety of functions, including the regulation of voluntary motor movements, procedural learning, and cognition. While there are complex interactions between the cerebellum and basal ganglia, particularly at the level of the thalamus, Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the basal ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deep cerebellar nuclei include the fastigial, interposed (which is further divided into the globose and emboliform nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. The axons of Purkinje cells synapse onto neurons in these nuclei. Importantly, Purkinje cells are inhibitory and utilize the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) to inhibit the cells of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A boy with a history of a fall from a tree presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his feet. Which of the following structures are involved? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The structure involved in causing lurching gait in the child is gluteus medius (marked as 2). The gluteus medius muscle is critical for stabilizing the pelvis during gait. When functioning normally, it prevents the pelvis from dropping to the opposite side during the swing phase of the walk. If injured or dysfunctional, such as might occur from a traumatic fall, the ability to maintain pelvic stability is compromised, leading to a lurching gait, known clinically as a Trendelenburg gait.

 

 

The structure shown in the image are :

 

1-Gluteus maximus

2-Gluteus medius

3-Piriformis

4-Sciatic nerve

 

Other Options:

 

1. Gluteus Maximus: The largest and most superficial of the gluteal muscles, mainly responsible for extension and lateral rotation of the hip. Its involvement is more related to power movements like climbing or jumping rather than gait stability.

 

3. Piriformis: A small muscle located deep in the buttock, behind the gluteus maximus. It helps with lateral rotation of the hip. Although it is near the sciatic nerve, it is less likely involved in producing a lurching gait unless it compresses the sciatic nerve, causing sciatica.

 

4. Sciatic Nerve: The largest nerve in the body, running from the lower back to the feet. While injury to this nerve can cause pain and weakness in the legs, it typically would not cause a lurching gait unless there is significant associated muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical Insight:

 

Injury to the gluteus medius or the superior gluteal nerve can lead to an inability to properly abduct the hip on the stance side, resulting in a drop of the pelvis on the contralateral side when the affected leg is weight-bearing. This is often demonstrated by a positive Trendelenburg sign and manifests as a compensatory lurch toward the affected side to maintain balance.

 

Additional Information

 

Gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip joint. Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus-

 

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • The actions of these muscles are affected when there is an injury to the superior gluteal nerve, neck of the femur, or loss of normal angulation of the shaft of the femur. This occurs in conditions like paralysis of the glutei, developmental dysplasia of the hip, etc.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb. This leads to a positive Trendelenburg's sign with a characteristic lurching gait - the patient lurches towards the affected side with contralateral pelvis drop.

questions.text: In given image, nucleus of marked nerve is related to (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervical spinal segment

 

The nerve marked in the image is the phrenic nerve. The phrenic nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the diaphragm, which is crucial for breathing. The mnemonic "3, 4, 5 keeps the diaphragm alive" helps to remember that the phrenic nerve arises from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5. This nerve travels downward, passing in front of the lung root, to reach the diaphragm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: The midbrain is not involved in the origin of the phrenic nerve. The midbrain primarily deals with functions such as vision, hearing, motor control, sleep/wake, arousal, and temperature regulation.

 

Option B. Pons: The pons is involved in various functions including breathing, communication between different parts of the brain, and sensations such as hearing, taste, and balance. However, it does not give rise to the phrenic nerve.

 

Option C. Medulla: The medulla oblongata regulates vital functions such as heart rate, breathing, and blood pressure. While it contains nuclei for several cranial nerves, it is not the origin of the phrenic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5, and is essential for diaphragm movement and breathing.

questions.text: Indicated structure gives origin to which of the following fiber (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dentato-rubral

 

The indicated structure in the provided image is the dentate nucleus. The dentate nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is the largest and most lateral of these nuclei. It is involved in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers. These fibers project from the dentate nucleus to the red nucleus in the midbrain, playing a crucial role in the coordination of motor movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebello-rubral: Incorrect because while it involves the cerebellum and red nucleus, the correct specific term for the fiber originating from the dentate nucleus is "dentato-rubral."

 

Option B. Cerebello-reticul: Incorrect because this option refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the reticular formation, not specifically involving the dentate nucleus.

 

Option C. Cerebello-vestibul: Incorrect because this refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the vestibular nuclei, which are involved in balance and spatial orientation, not related to the dentate nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers, which project to the red nucleus and are crucial for motor coordination.

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paratonsillar vein

 

Explanation:

 

In the case described, the patient likely underwent surgery for a peritonsillar abscess (aka Quinsy), a complication arising from tonsillitis. This condition can lead to significant swelling in the throat and difficulty swallowing. Post-operative bleeding in such cases, especially the continuous type noted as soaking through gauze, is most commonly associated with venous sources rather than arterial.

 

The given image is a cadaveric specimen with an arrow pointing to the tonsillar fossa. The paratonsillar / external palatine vein is the typical site of venous origin for post-tonsillectomy bleeding.

 

The paratonsillar vein, which is closely associated with the tonsillar bed and provides significant venous drainage for the tonsil, is the likely source of this bleeding. Venous bleeding tends to be continuous and can be persistent if the vein is not adequately secured during surgery.

 

Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery: The tonsils receive blood supply primarily from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. Injury to this artery during tonsillar surgery can cause bleeding, but the bleeding is usually brisk and bright red, and the artery would likely be cauterized or ligated during surgery to prevent such bleeding.

 

Option B. Ascending pharyngeal artery: It's a branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the pharynx, soft palate, and the tympanic cavity. While this artery does provide blood supply to the pharyngeal region, it's not as intimately associated with the tonsillar region as the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

 

Option D. Retromandibular vein: The retromandibular vein is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein in the parotid gland. It's located further away from the tonsillar region, and it's unlikely to be injured during procedures involving the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of the tonsils:

 

 

Arterial supply:

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.

 

Venous supply:

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.

 

Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:

 

1. Primary hemorrhage:

  • Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
  • Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

 

2. Reactionary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
  • It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
  • It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
  • If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.

 

3. Secondary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
  • It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
  • The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

questions.text: A woman with right-sided loss of sensations of both the upper and lower limb complains of shooting pain from her fingers to the right shoulder and a burning sensation when touching cold water. Motor functions are normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thalamus

 

The given clinical stem of a hemi-sensory loss and severe excruciating pain of the affected areas is suggestive of thalamic pain syndrome also known as Dejerine Roussy syndrome. Hence, thalamus marked as B is most likely to be involved.

 

The thalamus is a paired structure, with one thalamus on each side of the brain. It relays sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and regulates consciousness, sleep, and alertness. The thalamus has multiple nuclei, each serving different functions. The ventral posterior nucleus, for instance, is vital for relaying somatosensory information. If the thalamus is damaged, it can lead to loss of sensation, and in certain cases, even cause the burning, shooting pain and abnormal temperature sensations described in the scenario, which aligns with the symptoms of thalamic syndrome.

 

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

Option A.  A- Internal capsule

 

Option B. B- Thalamus

 

Option C. C- Subthalamic nucleus

 

Option D. D- Substantia nigra

 

Lesion in other three structures will lead to motor deficit and in question it is clearly mentioned that there is no motor deficit, only sensory deficit is the which  clearly indicates that the lesion lies in thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal capsule: The internal capsule is a bundle of white matter fibers that separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the lenticular nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus). The anterior limb separates the head of the caudate from the lenticular nucleus, while the posterior limb separates the thalamus from the lenticular nucleus. It contains ascending and descending axonal fibers running between the cerebral cortex and the brainstem/spinal cord. Damage to the internal capsule, especially its posterior limb, can cause contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia (motor deficits). However, the woman's motor functions are described as normal, making this a less likely option given the scenario.

 

Option C. Subthalamic nucleus: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the basal ganglia circuit and is specifically associated with motor function. Lesions of the subthalamic nucleus, particularly on one side, might result in hemiballismus, which is characterized by violent, flinging movements of the contralateral limbs. It is not typically associated with sensory disturbances, or the pain described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Substantia nigra: The substantia nigra is in the midbrain and plays a critical role in reward, addiction, and movement. It contains dopamine-producing neurons. The degeneration of these neurons is a hallmark of Parkinson's disease. Lesions in the substantia nigra would primarily produce motor symptoms, such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and tremors. It would not typically lead to the sensory disturbances described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thalamic pain syndrome is caused by the occlusion of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches. C/L hemisensory loss, which begins as numbness and escalates to cause intense burning pain in the affected areas, is what distinguishes it.

 

A thalamic lesion results in a breakdown in communication between the brain's afferent route and cortex because the thalamus serves as the site for the relay of sensory information between the periphery and cortex. The healing process following a thalamic infarct is painful.

questions.text: Artery supplying near marked structure is (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior interventricular artery

 

The anterior interventricular artery, also known as the left anterior descending artery (LAD), supplies the anterior portion of the interventricular septum. This artery runs along the anterior interventricular groove and is critical in providing blood to the front part of the heart, including the septum and the left ventricle. The LAD is often referred to as the "widowmaker" artery because blockage of this artery can lead to severe myocardial infarction, which is often fatal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left circumflex artery: This artery supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle but does not supply the anterior interventricular septum.

 

Option B. Left marginal artery: This artery branches off the circumflex artery and supplies the left ventricle's lateral wall, but it does not supply the interventricular septum.

 

Option D. Posterior interventricular artery: This artery supplies the posterior third of the interventricular septum but not the anterior portion. It runs in the posterior interventricular groove.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum and is critical for heart function, making it a key vessel in coronary circulation.

questions.text: Most common hernia in females (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

The most common type of hernia in females is the inguinal hernia, and specifically, the indirect inguinal hernia. This can be confusing because femoral hernias are indeed more common in females compared to males, but the indirect inguinal hernia remains the most prevalent overall in females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal hernia: Incorrect. While inguinal hernias are common, the direct inguinal hernia is less common than the indirect inguinal hernia in both males and females.

 

Option C. Femoral hernia: Incorrect. Femoral hernias are more frequently seen in females compared to males, but they are not the most common type of hernia in females overall.

 

Option D. Obturator hernia: Incorrect. Obturator hernias are rare and not the most common type of hernia in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In females, the most common type of hernia is the indirect inguinal hernia, despite femoral hernias being more common in females compared to males.

 

Incidence of Hernia in Females: Indirect inguinal Hernia > Direct inguinal Hernia > Femoral hernia

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. General somatic

2. General visceral

3. Special somatic

4. Special visceral
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2, 4, 1, 3

 

The question is regarding afferent columns hence we will only look at the afferent columns to arrange these options and not the whole arrangement of all the columns in the diagram.

 

The afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be categorized from medial to lateral into four types: general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, and special somatic.

 

 

 

The subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be organized from medial to lateral as follows:

 

2. General visceral: The general visceral column carries sensory information from the internal organs, such as the visceral sensations of hunger, fullness, and discomfort.

 

4. Special visceral: This column includes sensory input related to the special senses of taste and hearing. The special visceral sensory column carries information from the taste buds and the cochlea (auditory part of the ear).

 

1. General somatic: The general somatic column carries sensory information related to touch, temperature, pain, and pressure from the body's skin and musculoskeletal system.

 

3. Special somatic: This column contains sensory input related to the special senses of vision, equilibrium, and proprioception (awareness of body position). It includes input from the eyes, ears (for balance), and proprioceptors in muscles and joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the floor of the fourth ventricle, the arrangement of the afferent sensory columns from medial to lateral is - 2. General visceral, 4. Special visceral, 1. General somatic & 3. Special somatic

choices.text: Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue
Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold
Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females

questions.text: True statement regarding the breast (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold

 

The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of the breast tissue that extends into the axilla (armpit area). It passes through the anterior axillary fold, which is a region near the front of the underarm. This anatomical feature is important for surgical considerations, particularly in breast surgeries and examinations for breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue: This statement is incorrect. The superior and medial quadrant of the breast does not have more tissue compared to other quadrants. The distribution of tissue in the breast is such that no specific quadrant is known to universally have more tissue in every individual.

 

Option B. 10 lobules are present: This statement is incorrect. The human breast typically contains around 15-20 lobules, not just 10. These lobules are responsible for the production of milk and are connected to ducts that lead to the nipple.

 

Option D. Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females: While the nipple is located at the level of the 4th intercostal space in males. In females, its position can vary among individuals due to the pendulous nature of the breast. Factors such as age, breast size, and body position can influence the exact location of the nipple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold, which is an important anatomical detail relevant in breast examinations and surgeries.

questions.text: A patient who has taken the first COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. An astute nurse noticed that the shoulder was flabby, flat, and was asymmetrical. There was an associated loss of contour of the shoulder joint. Injury to which of the structures might have resulted and was avoidable?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Axillary nerve

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of injury to axillary nerve which leads to deltoid muscle palsy.

 

The deltoid muscle is supplied by the axillary nerve. Iatrogenic damage to the axillary nerve can happen during transaxillary procedures on the shoulder with lateral deltoid-splitting incisions or while administering IM injections inappropriately. But, note that this nerve is commonly injured during shoulder dislocation (most commonly anterior type) or fractures of the humeral neck as both the nerve and the posterior circumflex vessels (pass horizontally and posterior to the neck of the humerus).

 

 

Injury to the axillary nerve can lead to:

 

  • Weakness of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Retropulsion (extension of the shoulder with the arm abducted to 90 degrees) is impossible.
  • Atrophy of the Deltoid muscle leading to the loss of muscle contours of the shoulder
  • Loss of sensation in the Regimental badge area

 

The described symptoms point towards a condition known as "Shoulder Injury Related to Vaccine Administration" (SIRVA). SIRVA can occur if the vaccine is injected too high in the upper arm, potentially causing inflammation or damage to the structures underlying the deltoid muscle, especially the axillary nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotator Cuff: The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis) that stabilize and allow various movements of the shoulder joint. Injury to the rotator cuff often results from trauma, repetitive use, or degeneration and leads to pain, especially with overhead activities, and weakness in the arm. A rotator cuff injury would not typically cause the "flabby, flat, asymmetrical" appearance described unless there was a significant tear and muscle atrophy. However, this type of injury wouldn't be directly associated with vaccine administration.

 

Option B. Posterior Circumflex Artery: The posterior circumflex humeral artery is a branch of the axillary artery that runs posteriorly around the surgical neck of the humerus. Injury to this artery might result in bleeding and potentially hematoma formation but wouldn't lead to the described flabby, flat appearance of the shoulder or loss of contour.

 

Option C. Lateral Cutaneous Nerve of Arm: The lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, also known as the lateral brachial cutaneous nerve, is a sensory nerve that provides sensation to the lateral part of the upper arm. Injury to this nerve would result in sensory loss or tingling in its distribution area but would not cause the observed morphological changes or affect the contour of the shoulder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and supplies the deltoid muscle and the teres minor muscle. It also carries sensory fibers for the skin over a part of the deltoid (known as the "regimental badge area").

 

Damage to the axillary nerve can result from shoulder dislocations or, as in this case, a vaccine administered too high on the arm. Injury to the axillary nerve would cause paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to a flat shoulder appearance and loss of the normal rounded contour of the deltoid. Over time, if the nerve does not recover, the deltoid muscle may atrophy, further accentuating the flat appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome, is a neurological condition caused by a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the PICA, a major artery that supplies the medulla. It results from damage to multiple structures in the medulla, including the nuclei of cranial nerves (such as the nucleus ambiguus), the spinothalamic tract, and the descending sympathetic pathways.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior Cerebellar Artery: The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum. Blockage or injury to this artery can lead to symptoms related to dysfunction of the upper cerebellum but is not associated with the classic features of lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option C. Posterior Superior Cerebellar Artery: The posterior superior cerebellar artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and the superior cerebellar peduncle. It is not directly associated with the lateral medullary syndrome. Blockage of this artery can lead to symptoms related to the superior cerebellum but not the specific features seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option D. Cerebral Artery: The term "cerebral artery" is a broad term that refers to arteries supplying the brain, including the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Blockage or issues with these arteries can cause various types of strokes or neurological symptoms, but they are not directly related to lateral medullary syndrome, which specifically involves the medulla and the PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a major artery that supplies the lateral and posterior parts of the medulla, as well as the inferior surface of the cerebellum. When there is an issue with the PICA, such as a clot or blockage, it can affect the blood supply to the lateral medulla. This leads to the classic symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, including dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), ataxia (loss of coordination), and various sensory disturbances.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when there is aspiration in supine position? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Upper part of right inferior lobe

 

When a person is in the supine position (lying on their back), aspirated material is most likely to enter the superior basel segment of the right lower lobe (upper part of the right inferior lobe). The right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and more vertically oriented than the left main bronchus. This makes the right side more susceptible to aspiration in general. And in the supine position, gravity makes the superior basel segment of the lower lobes (particularly on the right side) the most dependent and thus the most likely site for aspiration.

 

Aspiration of gastric contents can cause chemical pneumonitis or aspiration pneumonia, which can affect different parts of the lung depending on the patient's position during aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingula: The lingula is a segment of the left upper lobe of the lung. It corresponds anatomically to the right middle lobe but on the left side. Due to the angulation of the main bronchi, it's less common for aspirated contents to travel into the left main bronchus when compared to the right. Thus, while it's possible for aspirated material to reach the lingula, especially in certain positions or conditions, it's not the most common site of aspiration.

 

Option C. Right superior lobe: This lobe isn't the primary location for aspiration in the supine position. However, if someone were to aspirate while standing or sitting upright, aspirated material might be more likely to enter the apical (uppermost) segments of the right upper lobe.

 

Option D. Right middle lobe: The right middle lobe, particularly its bronchus, is more susceptible to aspiration when an individual is in the lateral decubitus position (lying on their side). The lateral segment of the right middle lobe becomes the most dependent segment in this position. But again, in the supine position, the right middle lobe isn't the primary site of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient is in a supine position and aspirates, superior segment of the inferior lobes are the most commonly involved lung sites.

questions.text: Where is the SRY region located?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Short arm of Y chromosome

 

Explanation

 

  • The SRY gene is located on the short arm (p-arm) of the Y chromosome (Yp11). This gene is often referred to as the "master switch" for male development. It codes for a transcription factor that triggers the development of testes in an embryo, which, in turn, leads to the development of male reproductive structures.

 

  • It is an intron less sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome.
